column1: This is a list of Russian towns and cities that were renamed.
Historical reasons behind geographical renaming were
a particularly large number of cities and towns were renamed in Russia after the October Revolution of 1917
more renamings happened during the whole history of the Soviet Union for political reasons

column2: German cities around Königsberg were made part of the Kaliningrad Oblast exclave
column3: see list of cities and towns in East Prussia

column1: soon after the reconquest of Southern Sakhalin in 1945
column2: Japanese placenames were replaced with Russian ones.
many Chinese or Chinese-sounding place names in the Russian Far East were replaced with Russian-sounding ones
after the dissolution of the Soviet Union
column3: renamings (often for restoration of original names) happened

column1: In the list below sometimes the year of renaming appears in brackets after the new name.
Iletskaya Zashchita → Iletsk → Iletskoye → Iletskaya Zashchita → Sol-Iletsk
Novaya Derevnya → Alexandrovsky → Novonikolayevsky → Novonikolayevsk → Novosibirsk
Novaya Pokrovka → Svoboda (1943) → Liski → Georgiu-Dezh (1965) → Liski (1990)
Saint Petersburg (1703) → Petrograd (1914) → Leningrad (1924) → Saint Petersburg (1991)
Sergiyev Posad → Sergiyev → Zagorsk → Sergiyev Posad
Svyatoy Krest → Prikumsk → Budyonnovsk → Prikumsk → Budyonnovsk
Ust-Sheksna → Rybansk → Rybnaya Sloboda → Rybnoy → Rybinsk → Shcherbakov → Rybinsk → Andropov → Rybinsk
Voskresenskoye → Voskresensk → Istra (not to be confused with another Voskresensk)
Yama → Yamsky Gorodok → Yama → Yamburg → Kingisepp (1922)
